title.rendered: Senior Durham Professor’s £12,000 Expenses Claims on First Class Trains.

content.rendered:
Whilst Students at Durham are being expected to pay up to £8,000 a year for college accommodation the Monocle can reveal that senior staff at Durham spent collectively £12,366 on First Class trains last academic year.

A Monocle investigation into the expenses of Senior Staff can reveal that the £12,000 was spent by only seven Senior Managers at Durham University, almost half of which can be attributed to two members of staff, one of whom was amongst the highest paid of university officers.

In order to prevent the abuse of expenses Durham University has a clear policy which governs what constitutes a valid claim. This policy also explicitly covers the use of first-class rail travel. The expenses policy for Durham University, which was last updated this October states that the University will only accept expenses for First class rail travel in three instances.

Firstly, if there is a compelling and evidenced case of disability, impairment or health-related need. As far as the Monocle knows this condition does not apply to any members of the senior staff and is not stated in any expenses claims which were reviewed.

Secondly, if there is a “Compelling value-for-money case”. It is far from clear what this actually means given that in almost all situations a standard class ticket will offer greater value for money.

The cases reviewed include instances of last-minute ticket purchases because of academic conferences “overrunning”. In one instance a senior manager spent over £500 on one return trip from Durham to London, including underground fares. Another senior manager, claimed £129 for a return rail trip from Durham to London Kings Cross for the 28th of January. When this meeting had to be extended the manager then claimed another £174 for a first-class trip departing the following day. A different manager followed in similar fashion, as he claimed £168.65 for a return trip from Darlington to King’s Cross for the Office for Students conference in London. However, when the conference overran, the academic claimed an extra £72.95 for another first-class trip back to Darlington

The third and final exception from the prohibition of excessively expensive train travel is the case of “Exceptional operational need”. Given that the operational need would seem to be to get from A to B as swiftly and as conveniently as possible, it is hard to see how such a basis could legitimately support first class instead of standard class travel, unless, say, only first class travel was available. In order to qualify for this the Expenses and Hospitality Policy stipulates that approval needs to be sought in advance from the relevant University Executive Committee member and attached when claiming the expense, presumably this is done to deter the abuse of expenses claims.

However, each expenses claim  investigated by the Monocle is from a member  of the University Executive Committee and so it is entirely unclear how the requirement for advance approval operates as a meaningful check  as the “relevant University Executive Committee member” would be themselves.

One committee member appears to have claimed some £1703 in only three months. Another claimed for  the cost of a first-class trip from Darlington to Newcastle, a half an hour train.
